contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "labor" and "toil" mean basically the same thing. Paul uses them to emphasize how hard they worked. Alternate translation: "how hard we worked" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quote: τὸν κόπον ἡμῶν καὶ τὸν μόχθον

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "exhorting," "encouraging," and "urging" are used together to express how passionately Paul's group encouraged the Thessalonians. Alternate translation: "We were strongly encouraging you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quote: παρακαλοῦντες ὑμᾶς, καὶ παραμυθούμενοι, καὶ μαρτυρόμενοι ... ὑμᾶς
contextId.glQuote: exhorting you and encouraging and urging you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "affliction" explains why they are in "distress." Alternate translation: "in all our distress caused by our afflictions" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.quote: ἐπὶ πάσῃ τῇ ἀνάγκῃ καὶ θλίψει ἡμῶν
contextId.glQuote: in all our distress and affliction

contextId.occurrenceNote: Paul uses "encourage" and "exhort" to emphasize how strongly they encourage the believers. Alternate translation: "we strongly encourage you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
This is a doublet stating the same idea in two ways to reinforce the concept. Alternate translation: "do wrong things" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
